SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A WORD OF EXPLANATION TO THE READER

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada can answer all questions. It is impossible for anyone to answer all questions. Others may prove impossible for you to answer, or you may not have enough information about your family's experiences.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you wish to answer.

(4) All questionnaires
   ( ) Pioneer health conditions
   ( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
   ( ) Pioneer housing
   ( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
   ( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the respondent:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. If you can't answer a question, simply leave it blank.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1905, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer File: What Was Western Canadian Pioneer Life?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, send it to you.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train on to Brandon then the end by Rail.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc. I met some very interesting people along the way.

A. All types of conveyances were usually available. The most common was a pair of horses by slow transportation. Railroads and steamships were important forms of travel during this period. Because of the vast distances involved, people were very mobile and traveled by boat from city to city.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? If so, why?

There was a small number of dissatisfied people in the early 1920s who moved out of the valley to find work elsewhere.

35. Did many people return during the Depression?

Yes, many people returned during the Depression.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

In the district, I served as the first president of the local improvement club in Alameda and chaired its first meeting. I also served as the president of the local chamber of commerce for several years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district, mention it here (giving dates wherever possible). (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I was the first person to own an automobile in the district.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) the endowment of person suggesting place name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption (if any change in name since above); (4) date and reason for change.

Alameda was named by John George, the first settler of Alameda, California, or Arnold Alameda, who had come from Alameda, California, and settled in the area. The name was changed to Alameda in 1850, after the town of Alameda, California.

Poveshell was named by Mr. Poveshell, who came from Poveshell, Illinois, and settled in the area. The name was changed to Poveshell in 1850, after the town of Poveshell, Illinois.
